Okay, Gluten sensetivities definitley exsist. Both my parents are gluten-intolerant. Before "gluten-free" was a fad, my dad kept having horrible stomachaches after eating certain things so he experimented cutting different things out until he figured out cutting wheat out stopped his aching. Going gluten-free helped him lose a lot of weight, and increased his energy. So no, he's not celiac, he actually has a sensitivity.

 As for my mom, she had really bad arthritis in her knees and shoulders. It would take her 5 minutes to walk down our stairs. She went to the doctors and they diagnosed her with Lupus, an inflammation disease. After she cut out gluten, she went and got a second blood test and the doctors said if these were her first blood tests, they would have never diagnosed her with it. 

So there you have it, it's not a placebo, it's not non-exsistant, for some people, gluten really does cause a problem for their health. Please stop being so insensetive and skeptical when people like me have first hand experience with it.
 (side note: I went gluten free for 2 and a half years, I didn't notice a difference so I eat normally now)

The video content is wrong. Gluten sensitivity DOES NOT exist, or at least we should be skeptical about it. There have been multiple double blind placebo controlled tests whereby self-proclaimed people with 'gluten sensitivity' were provided with foods, which either had gluten added or not (the latter being the control/placebo). 

They found no difference in symptoms between the samples, indicating gluten has NOTHING to do with it. Instead, scientists point towards FODMAPS, a series of short chain carbohydrates that are difficult to digest by the human body. It is these that are linked to the symptoms associated with gluten sensitivity. Wheat is one of them, which is where the confusion probably stems from.

http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0016508513007026

I'm a celiac, and honestly I'm rather glad because the amount of opportunities I've been offered to eat unhealthy glutenous foods (such as cake at social events or coffee shops) is countless, and I'm pretty sure if I did include gluten in my diet I would be a lot heavier and unhealthier than I am now. 

There are a lot more options available for celiacs such as myself as time as progressed which I am grateful for, but as a celiac that lives around non-celiacs, my diet is a lot more healthier. I can't just pop down to the bakery and buy whatever I feel like, and more often that not cafes, coffee shops, restaurants etc don't have the gluten free option, and it they DO, its usually just simply an omelette or  jacket potato which is healthier than most of the other options. 

Also when diagnosed as celiac, iron deficiency usually comes as very likely, which mean I must take iron supplements and include a lot more iron in my diet (as found in broccoli, raisins, red meat, spinach etc) which is a lot healthier. 

TL;DR I disagree that on average being a celiac is unhealthier than not.

It's not so much the gluten in food that attacks the body but more so the antibodies that the body produces when facing the protein. These antibodies attack the villi found in the small intestine and prevent celiacs, like me, from absorbing sufficient nutrients. Before finding out I was a sufferer, I was unable to enough of the good stuff like iron and zinc. I ate a pretty healthy diet, exceeding my 5 a day and so on and so forth yet although I didn't have the typical issues like bloating and stomach pain, my hair was thin, my skin lacked colour and I had little energy. A little while after being diagnosed and omitting gluten I grew 3 inches and had zest. In saying that I have to take some supplements such as folic acid, an important substance found in bread. I feel unless, like me, you need to keep away from the grains it wouldn't be greatly beneficial towards your health to cancel it out of your diet

If we look at the structure of human teeth, we see the number of 32.
8 are incisor's for cutting, vegetable matter.
4 are canine for tearing, carnivorous, although these are fairly redundant as a real tearing tooth, and are more a cross between a molar and an incisor.
20 are molar, designed for grinding.
By far the majority of human teeth are for grinding grains. Look at any animal, their teeth will tell you what they eat.
The staple food for the majority of the worlds population is grain, rice predominately. Too bad, most of that is dead, white polished, stripped of it's germ and roughage and essential vitamin value. If you plant it, it doesn't grow, unlike brown rice.
Anyway, I digress. Gluten to me, sounds a lot like glutton. Which is a BIG problem in affluent country's.
We are confronted with RACKS of junk food from the exit of every shop that is remotely connected with food and a lot that aren't, like petrol station's. Temptation is all around, backed up by corporate advertising telling us these foods are healthy, they give us energy. Lie's... The most dangerous of these refined 'foods' is white sugar, the most addictive and destructive substance on the planet. Don't think your addicted to sugar? Here's a challenge. Quit all refined sugar, and foods that contain it, for 10 days. Keep a diary of your feelings.
It is unnecessary, un-nutritious  empty of food value. Which is why it leaves you dissatisfied and still hungry, so you can't stop eating it. Good for food corporations, not for your health, nor the world health.
Our digestive systems are designed for whole, simple foods. Whole grains, vegetable's, bean's, etc. In season, grown in the climate we live in.
Confused eating is the cause of most digestive dis-ease and a great deal of others.
While I'm on my soapbox, dig this. Mastication, chewing... Is 90% of the pre-digestive process. So slow down, savoir the flavour, take your time.
OK, I hear you say, what about the Inuit's. They don't eat grain's and veggie's.
True, but they do eat according to their environment, their climatic conditions, their natural surroundings. Human's are omnivores but only if we eat according to our climatic and environmental conditions. In other words according to nature.
I could go on and on with more explanations. However, hope this is at least food for thought.
If your interested in this line of inquiry. Read 'Sugar Blues'  by William Duffy, would be a good start, Couple quid on Amazon, the price of a packet of biscuits could save your health, life, and a lot of dough. Whatever you eat, don't eat more than you need!

It is likely that there is nothing wrong with gluten itself. But has anyone ever looked in to the common ingredients that are almost always found along with gluten? For example, folic acid. It is commonly confused to be the same thing as the naturally occuring folate and forced on all of America and other countries as a healthy "vitamin". But did you know that a "gene defect" was recently discovered called MTHFR that concluded ONLY HALF of the population can properly metabolize it in the body? Go look at the ingredients in your foods in your fridge and pantry. I guarantee you will find an abundance of foods containing folic acid. This is due to the law passed in 1990 that made fortifying certain foods with folic acid and other questionable synthetic vitamins to become mandatory. And did you know there is a such thing as "folic acid poisoning"? Side effects include digestive problems, nausea, loss of appetite, bloating, gas, a bitter or unpleasant taste in the mouth, sleep disturbances, depression, excessive excitement, irritability and a zinc deficiency. More severe signs include psychotic behavior, numbness or tingling, mouth pain, weakness, trouble concentrating, confusion, fatigue and even seizures. In contrast, there is absolutely no health risk associated with folate intake. This information really makes me wonder.

I have celiac disease. Personally, I think that the only reason people claim it to be a "miracle diet" is because you have to say no to things. Like if you are at your average donut shop with friends, you'll have to pass. The same while other people are eating regular pizza, cupcakes, bagels, and other carb-filled, unhealthy foods. Not to say that there are no gluten free options, but these are not as convenient and readily available as gluten. In my experience, most gluten free food is kept in the freezer and must be cooked in a microwave or oven to eat. So it takes more planning.  It has nothing to do with the ingredients. It just gives you a reason to say no to carb-y, unhealthy food. Our society (especially in 'Murica), food is not thought of as a necessity, but also a hobby and something to do when you are bored. Staying on a gluten free diet will limit this unhealthy gluttony simply because it is more difficult to find and/ or prepare food. So, personally, I do not think you have to give up gluten to be healthy. Just watch what you eat and make sure you are getting the right amount of nutrients.

OK, here is a question for you. 
My son is Type 1 diabetic. Recently we were having trouble getting rid of his ketones. As in, he had high ketones nearly every day for over a month and had visited the ER 3 times during that time period.

Before this extended issue, we noticed that, after a ketone fit (as I call them) for about a week following, every time he ate anything with bread in it, he would throw up. I mentioned this to the doctors multiple times over the course of about 2 years, and no one did anything.

SO, after this BIG issue, they finally checked and said he was "light possitive" which was not an actual positive and to not change his diet. Instead insisting that it had to be something else. Is his insulin good, are his ketostrips good, do his needle tips work, is his meter working, are we adding everythign up correctly... etc.

Yes to everything. So finally, I said forget it and cut out gluten. Within a day and a half, ketones were gone, and stayed gone for nearly a month. WELL, the day before yesterday, they told me that there is absolutely NO WAY that a gluten allergy (no, they said celiac disease) could cause ketones, that it was impossible, and to put him back on a regular diet.

Ok, fine. Back on a normal diet he goes and he had a regular sandwich for lunch and we had pizza for dinner. By dinner time he had light ketones, and by bedtime they were high. The following morning they were still high, as were his blood sugars and he was in extreme abdominal pain and throwing up.

He had no gluten at all yesterday and we pumped a great deal of insulin into him to bring down his numbers and get rid of ketones (all with the doctors on the phone with me of course) and they finally had me bring him into the ER where they basically just pumped him full of fluids, checked his ketones once and sent him home.

SO, my question is, if gluten is NOT the cause of his high ketones, then what else could I have possibly taken away when I make him gluten free that WOULD cause the problem?
